net.nexttext.behaviour.physics
Class Bounce

java.lang.Object
  net.nexttext.behaviour.AbstractAction
      net.nexttext.behaviour.physics.PhysicsAction
          net.nexttext.behaviour.physics.Bounce
All Implemented Interfaces:
Action
public class Bounce
extends PhysicsAction

This action performs collision response on two objects by moving them apart and reflects their velocity.

Method Detail

behave

public Action.ActionResult behave(TextObject toA,
                                  TextObject toB)
Performs collision response on toA and toB by pushing them apart an reflecting their velocity.

Objects will not collide if one is a child of the other.

Specified by:
behave in interface Action
Overrides:
behave in class AbstractAction

protected void reflectVelocity(PVectorProperty velProp,
                               PVector mtd)

getVectorToSeparateAFromB

protected PVector getVectorToSeparateAFromB(Polygon A,
                                            Polygon B)
Returns the smallest vector which pushes A away from B.

Even though odds are we'll be dealing mostly with boxes, this method supports arbitrary convex polygons. In order to do so, we need to test with the axis perpendicular to every edge of each polygon.

Note that it returns a zero vector if A and B do not intersect.

getVectorToSeparateAFromBInner

protected PVector getVectorToSeparateAFromBInner(Polygon A,
                                                 Polygon B)
Returns the smallest vector which pushes A away from B and is perpendicular to one of A's edges.

AxisSeparatesPolygons

protected PVector AxisSeparatesPolygons(PVector axis,
                                        Polygon A,
                                        Polygon B)
Return a vector to move Polygon A away from Polygon B on the given axis, or the zero vector if they don't intersect.

calculateInterval

protected Bounce.Interval calculateInterval(PVector axis,
                                            Polygon P)
Projects a Polygon P onto axis N and returns the min/max interval of the projection.
